pullRequest.body:
If $M$ is an $R$-module, $N$ a submodule and $S$ a subset of $R$. Then we can define $S \cdot N$ to be the smallest submodule containing all $s \cdot n$ where $s \in S$ and $n \in N$

---

nodes.body: I think [in locale Pointwise](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/20fb81821d7bb3b3bff5da563638068af7b19108/Mathlib/Data/Set/Pointwise/Basic.lean#L327) this is even a MulAction.

> I think [in locale Pointwise](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/20fb81821d7bb3b3bff5da563638068af7b19108/Mathlib/Data/Set/Pointwise/Basic.lean#L327) this is even a MulAction.

It is a distributive multicative action! Thanks for pointing this out.

> It is a distributive multicative action! Thanks for pointing this out.

Thanks for confirming! If `Set R` were a Semiring I think we can also show it's a [Module](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/Basic.html#Module), but it's not (distributivity doesn't hold). So we have to wait until we generalize the typeclass assumptions of `Module` for that.

> ! If `Set R` were a Semiring

It is when using the SetSemiring alias
I think we might already have a `Module (Ideal R) (Submodule R M)` instance; is this new instance the same a that one composed with Ideal.span?

> It is when using the SetSemiring alias

That's using union as addition, not pointwise addition inherited from addition on R.

> I think we might already have a Module (Ideal R) (Submodule R M) instance; is this new instance the same a that one composed with Ideal.span?

I think yes (and [loogle](https://loogle.lean-fro.org/?q=Module+%28Ideal+_%29+%28Submodule+_+_%29) found [Submodule.moduleSubmodule](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/Ideal/Operations.html#Submodule.moduleSubmodule)). (Should we restrict to CommSemiring?)

> > It is when using the SetSemiring alias
> 
> 
> 
> That's using union as addition, not pointwise addition inherited from addition on R.
> 
> 
> 
> > I think we might already have a Module (Ideal R) (Submodule R M) instance; is this new instance the same a that one composed with Ideal.span?
> 
> 
> 
> I think yes (and [loogle](https://loogle.lean-fro.org/?q=Module+%28Ideal+_%29+%28Submodule+_+_%29) found [Submodule.moduleSubmodule](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/Ideal/Operations.html#Submodule.moduleSubmodule)). (Should we restrict to CommSemiring?)

Should I re-implement this in terms of span composing with soul then?
I suspect this has the same problem as you remarked about for the case of non-commutative rings `R`
Do you actually care about the non-commutative case?

> Do you actually care about the non-commutative case?

No,not really. But we should have it work for noncomm cases in case other people care about them right?

> > Do you actually care about the non-commutative case?
> 
> No,not really. But we should have it work for noncomm cases in case other people care about them right?

Only if we think the generalization is reasonable; for instance you say that

> `Submodule.pointwiseDistribMulAction` wants `[SMulCommClass Î± R M]`, so when we write down `r â€¢ N`, we need a type class `SMulCommClass R R M`, but `R` is assumed to be semiring here not necessarily commutative, so we can't write `r â€¢ N`?

One option is of course to redefine `r â€¢ N` as the smallest submodule with the property you describe, but then it is no longer the case that it is equal to `r â€¢ (N : Set M)`. Arguably, the value in _that_ definition in the first place is that it coincides.

Maybe it's obvious to you that this generalization is the right one, but in cases where it's not its often best to leave the generalization for someone who does care about it, so that they can ensure the generalization goes in the right directions.

Note: I have pushed an update to the lean toolchain because this PR was on a [buggy version](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113488-general/topic/Potential.20data.20loss.20from.20.60lake.20clean.60.20with.204.2E2.2E0-rc2.2F3/near/397875701) of the toolchain. **WARNING**: checking out old commits of this PR using v4.2.0-rc2 or v4.2.0-rc3 can cause `lake clean` to delete your mathlib folder! If you need to do so, make sure to delete `lakefile.olean` manually before running any `lake` commands.

> If these lemmas are already in the `Submodule` namespace, maybe we don't need to repeat `submodule` in the lemma name?

`submodule` has been removed from all names

LGTM modulo the minor comment above

If these lemmas are already in the `Submodule` namespace, maybe we don't need to repeat `submodule` in the lemma name?
bors merge

```suggestion
protected def pointwiseSetSMulSubmodule : SMul (Set R) (Submodule R M) where
```
This indentation is the Lean 3 style, not the Lean 4 style, which would indent all but the first line by an extra level.
hopefully, indentation now is okay now

Is this is the same as the following?
```suggestion
  smul s N := â¨† r âˆˆ s, r â€¢ N
```

Or perhaps
```suggestion
  smul s N := sSup <| (. â€¢ N) '' s
```
If you don't like the bInf
They are the same, but I think defining it to be `sInf ...` is very intuitive, it is the smallest submodule containing all the `r \bu n` for `r \in s` and `n \in N`
Instead of changing definition, maybe I just prove that `sInf { p | âˆ€ â¦ƒr : Râ¦„ â¦ƒn : Mâ¦„, r âˆˆ s â†’ n âˆˆ N â†’ r â€¢ n âˆˆ p }` is â¨† r âˆˆ s, r â€¢ N?

Correct me if I am wrong here:
`Submodule.pointwiseDistribMulAction` wants `[SMulCommClass Î± R M]`, so when we write down `r â€¢ N`, we need a type class `SMulCommClass R R M`, but `R` is assumed to be semiring here not necessarily commutative, so we can't write `r â€¢ N`?

So I proved this
```lean
lemma set_smul_submodule_eq_iSup [SMulCommClass R R M] :
    s â€¢ N = â¨† (r âˆˆ s), r â€¢ N := ...
```

If we define it as `sInf`, then we don't need `SMulCommClass R R M` assumption
Another justification of using `sInf` is this proof that `s \bu t \bu N = (s * t) \bu N` is simple when we know that set-smul-submodule is the smallest of something. @eric-wieser

Can you name this section, and update the "#implementation notes" in the module docstring to make it clear that the lemmas from this point on are not "direct copies of lemmas from
`GroupTheory/Submonoid/Pointwise.lean`."?
done
Should this be upgraded to an iff?
I added an `iff` version as `set_smul_submodule_le_iff`
I think there should be a `s â€¢ p â‰¤ t â€¢ q` lemma for `s â‰¤ t` and `p â‰¤ q`.
see `set_smul_submodule_le_of_le_le`

```suggestion
  set_smul_submodule_le s N
  { carrier := {m : M | prop m}
    add_mem' := Î» {x y} â†¦ @add x y
    zero_mem' := zero
    smul_mem' := smulâ‚ }
    smulâ‚€ hx
```
I think the style guideline still prefers this?
thanks
I think a better simp lemma would be `(âˆ… : Set R) â€¢ N = âŠ¥` (or both if there would be DTT issues)
changed to `empty_smul_submodule`
I think `s â€¢ âŠ¥ = âŠ¥` should be separated out as a (simp) lemma since the simp normal form is `âŠ¥` rather than `0`.
added `set_smul_bot_submodule`
I think there should instead be a lemma showing that the action is equal to `Submodule.hasSMul'` for ideals, and this is then just `Submodule.ideal_span_singleton_smul`.
`s` is not necessarily a singleton ... I agree that `I â€¢ N = (I : Set R') â€¢ N` is a useful lemma, but I'm not sure it helps with the proof.
Do we not have `Ideal.span s â€¢ N = s â€¢ N`? We should also have such a lemma in any case.
Has this been addressed?

Is this lemma necessary, it is just two rewrites away
```lean
lemma span_smul_submodule'
    (s : Set R) (N : Submodule R M) :
    (Ideal.span s) â€¢ N = s â€¢ N := by
  rw [smul_eq_set_smul, Submodule.span_smul_submodule]
```
Yes, because `smul_eq_set_smul` is an unfolding lemma.
Where is `smul_eq_set_smul` (edit: I see it now)? And I'd argue that `span_smul_submodule'` is necessary and `span_smul_submodule` isn't if you only want to choose one.
And this should be called `span_set_smul_submodule` or `coe_span_smul_submodule` if you want to keep it.
Done, thanks for the naming suggestion.

```suggestion
@[simp, norm_cast]
lemma coe_set_smul : (I : Set R) â€¢ N = I â€¢ N :=
```

```suggestion
    Ideal.span s â€¢ N = s â€¢ N := by
```

```suggestion
@[simp]
lemma span_smul_submodule'
```

This does not read as you intend it to. I read this as
```
def thing [SMulCommClass R R M] (s : Set R) : DistribMulAction s (Submodule R M)
```
not
```
def thing [SMulCommClass R R M] : DistribMulAction (Set R) (Submodule R M)
```
Here's one solution:
```suggestion
/-- In a ring, sets acts on submodules. -/
```

```suggestion

@[simp] lemma empty_smul_submodule : (âˆ… : Set R) â€¢ N = âŠ¥ := by
```

```suggestion
@[elab_as_elim]
lemma set_smul_submodule_inductionOn {prop : M â†’ Prop} (x : M)
```

```suggestion
Let `s âŠ† R` be a set and `N â‰¤ M` be a submodule, then `s â€¢ N` is the smallest submodule containing
all `r â€¢ n` where `r âˆˆ s` and `n âˆˆ N`.
```

Does this work?
```suggestion
    ({r} : Set R) â€¢ N = r â€¢ N := by
```

```suggestion
lemma sup_set_smul_submodule (s t : Set R) :
```
This should have a `/-! ### Subheading -/` and perhaps a few sentences summarizing what this section is about.
done in [28d6404](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/7140/commits/28d64046205bb588e7dc738321c3bb835505708d)
Can you generalize `prop` to `motive : (x : M) â†’ x âˆˆ s â€¢ N â†’ Prop` so that it works with `induction using`?
Done in[28d6404](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/7140/commits/28d64046205bb588e7dc738321c3bb835505708d)

This map has a name:
```suggestion
      (N.subtype.comp (Finsupp.lsum R <| DistribMulAction.toLinearMap _ _))
```
Thanks!

This generalizes to
```suggestion
protected def pointwiseSetSMul : SMul (Set S) (Submodule R M) where
```
right? How may of the other results also generalize for free?
What is `S` here? Is it another ring of which `M` is a module?
Yes; or more generally, a monoid for which it is a `distribMulAction`.
Everything upto induction principal should work mutatis mutandis. My hunch is that if we further assume `[SMulCommClass R S M]` then everything should work?

So the generalized principal is this 
```lean
variable {s N} in
@[elab_as_elim]
lemma set_smul_inductionOn {motive : (x : M) â†’ (_ : x âˆˆ s â€¢ N) â†’ Prop}
    (x : M)
    (hx : x âˆˆ s â€¢ N)
    (smulâ‚€ : âˆ€ â¦ƒr : Sâ¦„ â¦ƒn : Mâ¦„ (memâ‚ : r âˆˆ s) (memâ‚‚ : n âˆˆ N),
      motive (r â€¢ n) (mem_set_smul_of_mem_mem memâ‚ memâ‚‚))
    (smulâ‚ : âˆ€ (r : R) â¦ƒm : Mâ¦„ (mem : m âˆˆ s â€¢ N) ,
      motive m mem â†’ motive (r â€¢ m) (Submodule.smul_mem _ r mem)) --
    (add : âˆ€ â¦ƒmâ‚ mâ‚‚ : Mâ¦„ (memâ‚: mâ‚ âˆˆ s â€¢ N) (memâ‚‚ : mâ‚‚ âˆˆ s â€¢ N),
      motive mâ‚ memâ‚ â†’ motive mâ‚‚ memâ‚‚ â†’ motive (mâ‚ + mâ‚‚) (Submodule.add_mem _ memâ‚ memâ‚‚))
    (zero : motive 0 (Submodule.zero_mem _)) :
    motive x hx :=
  let âŸ¨_, hâŸ© := set_smul_le s N
    { carrier := { m | âˆƒ (mem : m âˆˆ s â€¢ N), motive m mem },
      zero_mem' := âŸ¨Submodule.zero_mem _, zeroâŸ©
      add_mem' := fun âŸ¨mem, hâŸ© âŸ¨mem', h'âŸ© â†¦ âŸ¨_, add mem mem' h h'âŸ©
      smul_mem' := fun r x âŸ¨mem, hâŸ© â†¦ âŸ¨_, smulâ‚ r mem hâŸ© }
    (fun _ _ mem mem' â†¦ âŸ¨mem_set_smul_of_mem_mem mem mem', smulâ‚€ mem mem'âŸ©) hx
  h
```

But to change the next lemma 
```lean
lemma set_smul_eq_map [SMulCommClass R R N] [Module S N]  [SMulCommClass S R N] :
    s â€¢ N =
    Submodule.map
      (N.subtype.comp (Finsupp.lsum R <| DistribMulAction.toLinearMap _ _))
      (Finsupp.supported N R s) := by
```
I need `N` to be both a `R`-submodule and `S`-submodule, so I included `[Module S N]`, can I somehow say this module structure is restricted from `[Module S M]`, or should I just I added some assumption like `\forall s \in S, n \in N, s \bu n \in N`
Is perhaps [`Subbimodule`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/Bimodule.html#Subbimodule.mk) relevant?
I think I would just leave this one ungeneralized

In [7d37123](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/7140/commits/7d371236ab626d2912422f17efab1875d1b68609) and [eecb383](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/7140/commits/eecb383e36ab97c536af331630659391d8d2df5b), the generalization has been done. Things that are not generalized were left some comments explaining why they can't or won't be generalized

If we generalize so that `r â€¢ N` makes sense for all `r : S`, then `Submodule.singleton_set_smul`
  and `Submodule.singleton_set_smul` can be generalized as well. We can prove `x âˆˆ ({r} : Set S) â€¢ N â†” âˆƒ (m : M), m âˆˆ N âˆ§ x = r â€¢ m` but we can't say `({r} : Set R) â€¢ N = r â€¢ N`

```suggestion
/-- Subset of a ring has a multiplicative action on its submodules. -/
```
This sentence sounds weird to me. In particular "its submodules" seems to be referring to "submodules of R".
I don't have a better alternative though so I'm fine if this is not changed.

How about
```suggestion
/-- A subset of a ring `R` has a multiplicative action on submodule of a module over `R`. -/
```

Ooops, I made a typo in my previous suggestion.
```suggestion
/-- A subset of a ring `R` has a multiplicative action on submodules of a module over `R`. -/
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: In a ring, sets act on submodules

nodes.body: I think [in locale Pointwise](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/20fb81821d7bb3b3bff5da563638068af7b19108/Mathlib/Data/Set/Pointwise/Basic.lean#L327) this is even a MulAction.

> I think [in locale Pointwise](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/20fb81821d7bb3b3bff5da563638068af7b19108/Mathlib/Data/Set/Pointwise/Basic.lean#L327) this is even a MulAction.

It is a distributive multicative action! Thanks for pointing this out.

> It is a distributive multicative action! Thanks for pointing this out.

Thanks for confirming! If `Set R` were a Semiring I think we can also show it's a [Module](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/Basic.html#Module), but it's not (distributivity doesn't hold). So we have to wait until we generalize the typeclass assumptions of `Module` for that.

> ! If `Set R` were a Semiring

It is when using the SetSemiring alias
I think we might already have a `Module (Ideal R) (Submodule R M)` instance; is this new instance the same a that one composed with Ideal.span?

> It is when using the SetSemiring alias

That's using union as addition, not pointwise addition inherited from addition on R.

> I think we might already have a Module (Ideal R) (Submodule R M) instance; is this new instance the same a that one composed with Ideal.span?

I think yes (and [loogle](https://loogle.lean-fro.org/?q=Module+%28Ideal+_%29+%28Submodule+_+_%29) found [Submodule.moduleSubmodule](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/Ideal/Operations.html#Submodule.moduleSubmodule)). (Should we restrict to CommSemiring?)

> > It is when using the SetSemiring alias
> 
> 
> 
> That's using union as addition, not pointwise addition inherited from addition on R.
> 
> 
> 
> > I think we might already have a Module (Ideal R) (Submodule R M) instance; is this new instance the same a that one composed with Ideal.span?
> 
> 
> 
> I think yes (and [loogle](https://loogle.lean-fro.org/?q=Module+%28Ideal+_%29+%28Submodule+_+_%29) found [Submodule.moduleSubmodule](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/Ideal/Operations.html#Submodule.moduleSubmodule)). (Should we restrict to CommSemiring?)

Should I re-implement this in terms of span composing with soul then?
I suspect this has the same problem as you remarked about for the case of non-commutative rings `R`
Do you actually care about the non-commutative case?

> Do you actually care about the non-commutative case?

No,not really. But we should have it work for noncomm cases in case other people care about them right?

> > Do you actually care about the non-commutative case?
> 
> No,not really. But we should have it work for noncomm cases in case other people care about them right?

Only if we think the generalization is reasonable; for instance you say that

> `Submodule.pointwiseDistribMulAction` wants `[SMulCommClass Î± R M]`, so when we write down `r â€¢ N`, we need a type class `SMulCommClass R R M`, but `R` is assumed to be semiring here not necessarily commutative, so we can't write `r â€¢ N`?

One option is of course to redefine `r â€¢ N` as the smallest submodule with the property you describe, but then it is no longer the case that it is equal to `r â€¢ (N : Set M)`. Arguably, the value in _that_ definition in the first place is that it coincides.

Maybe it's obvious to you that this generalization is the right one, but in cases where it's not its often best to leave the generalization for someone who does care about it, so that they can ensure the generalization goes in the right directions.

If you need to do so, make sure to delete `lakefile.olean` manually before running any `lake` commands.
If these lemmas are already in the `Submodule` namespace, maybe we don't need to repeat `submodule` in the lemma name?

`submodule` has been removed from all names
